title: For Sale:  Smith S&W 6450 Very Rare 45 ACP Transition from 645 to 4506
postcontent:
Short Description:

Great find for a Smith collector.  Unique and rare.  

Though marked as a model 645, this was shipped as a model 6450 (Box label only.  See below for links to the interesting history of this transition model).  One of about 475 manufactured in 1988.  It is unique as it has a Gen 3 frame but a Gen 2 slide, yet is marked as a Gen 2 model 645.  From my research, even then there are several variations of this model.

This was an agency gun.  The finish has been refreshed and should rate NRA “Excellent”.  Very small, lightly engraved agency markings have been left to allow the history of this gun to live on (left front fluted area of the slide, curved transition between front-strap and trigger guard and the bottom edges on the rear of the slide).  When you look at the gun, you wouldn't know they are there unless you point them out.  Did my best to show them in the photos.

Restoration includes complete detail strip (disassembled), cleaned and new Wolff springs installed.  New OEM rear sight.  New OEM Delron grip.  Two magazines, one OEM and one aftermarket.  New MTM pistol case.  Other parts were replaced and I will include the old parts, except the beat up Hogue grips it had.  It's now as near new as possible and a handsome example of a rare Smith 45.

My slant on this hobby is restoring S&W stainless semi-autos to new or near new condition. 
I take pride in my work.  This is offered with a 3 day “no fire” examination period.

Payment via USPS Money Order, Certified check or Chase Bank “QuickPay”.  I'll accept credit cards if you'll cover the 3.9% fee I'm charged.  Shipping is $25.00 USPS to your FFL.  Add for insurance over the standard $50.

Now for my rather breathy, collector kind of guy description:

This is one of those scarce/rare S&W variants that S&W collectors enjoy adding to their collection.  Makes for a good conversation piece regarding the Smith “Model Numbering” system, which was a bit screwy back in the day, as well as the Gen 2 – Gen 3 transition period.  This was manufactured during the 1988 transition period and is a Gen 3 Model 645.

Huh?....

Yup. 

Well, not quite a Gen 2... or a Gen 3.

This is a "transition" model S&W from 1988 when they were transitioning from the Model 645 to the 4506.  These were shipped as a Model 6450 (box label only).  According to the Blue Book of Gun Values and other sources, only around 475 were made, some shipped to and supplied to RSR, some went to the S&W Performance Center and others, like this, made their way onto the market as a Model 645 with unusual configurations.  A confusing time but not unusual in the manufacturing world during a tooling changeover.

The frame is stamped as a "Model 645" but it's really a Gen 3 “4506” frame.  It has Delron wrap around grips (no metal back-strap like the 645 or threaded holes for the 645 screw on grips) and is machined for the "Left Hand" magazine release option.  Also, the safety/decocker "dots" are not on the frame like a 4506 but instead, are on the slide, as on the Gen 2.

Are you confused yet?  Ya... that's the way it was then too.  But that's the fun of this one.

As for the slide, the front integrated ramp site with a red plastic insert is replaced by a removable dovetailed white dot blade style site.  And as I already mentioned, the safety/decocker dots are on the slide instead of the frame as on a 4506.  You'll also notice the top of the slide has a sharp cut top strap.

One more thing I noticed when researching this on the Net:  I found a photo of this same configuration but... looking on the “right” side of the frame... the photo I viewed showed the magazine release as only round shape, so... a left hand mag release wouldn't have worked.  The one I'm offering here has a Gen 3 frame cut for the left hand mag release option!
